title: Opinion: While looking back at their title, Raptors believe in what they have this season
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Trysta Krick and Jeff Zillgitt break down the potential for the New Orleans Pelicans this season. USA TODAY

TORONTO — Nick Nurse thought he was ready for the Toronto Raptors’ ring ceremony and raising of a championship banner.

He wasn't.

"It was a more lot more (emotional) than I thought it was going to be," the Toronto coach said. "I guess I just didn’t prepare myself very well. I thought they were just going to hand us a ring."

That’s not how it works. Toronto’s game-night operations staff produced a video, showing highlights from the Raptors’ postseason run, including the Game 1 loss to the Orlando Magic in the first round, Kawhi Leonard’s bounce-around-the-rim 3-pointer at the buzzer, and Kyle Lowry securing the basketball in the final seconds of Toronto’s championship-clinching victory in Game 6 against Golden State.

"I haven’t really watched many of those games, but you’re around enough and see enough of the highlights and there’s that shot he hit and that shot he hit. It’s really something," Nurse said.

Coaches like to look ahead, not back, especially when talking to reporters. But there’s one game when a team must look back and appreciate what it accomplished. That’s the season opener for the champions when they receive the elaborate, over-sized rings and see the banner unveiled.

"It’s definitely going to an amazing feeling to be able to come back after your career is done and see that (banner) and be a part of that team, the first (Raptors) team to do it," guard Normal Powell said.

Front office staffers, including president Masai Ujiri and general manager Bobby Webster, received their rings, then the coaching staff got theirs and finally the players, with the heartbeat of the Raptors, Kyle Lowry, the last one to get a ring from ownership after a hug from NBA Commissioner Adam Silver.

ZION INJURY: Rookie's absence deflates NBA season before it begins

BOLD PREDICTIONS: Looking into the crystal ball for 2019-20 season

After all that emotion, the Raptors still had a game to play against the New Orleans Pelicans.

Nothing was going to take the shine off the 2019-20 season opener for the Raptors. Not even a loss to the Pelicans would’ve ruined this night, a night Raptors fans waited 25 years for.

The Raptors made sure it was a perfect night, pulling out a 130-122 overtime victory over the Zion Williamson-less Pelicans.

Fresh off signing a four-year, $130 million extension, forward Pascal Siakam had 34 points, 18 rebounds and five assists. Fred VanVleet added 34 points and seven assists.

"We will see them grow all year and continue to see them flourish," said Lowry who finished with 22 points, six assists and five rebounds.

And here’s the little secret that won’t be a secret for long: the Raptors are good, even without Kawhi Leonard (off the Clippers) and Danny Green (off to the Lakers).

The Raptors are the rare defending champs who most NBA followers aren’t predicting to win their conference. The Raptors are also the rare defending champions whose best player left for another team after winning the title.

But they really don’t care about predictions.

STAFF PICKS: Award and championship predictions for 2019-20

Asked what he learned about the Raptors during the preseason, veteran big man Serge Ibaka said, "We’re still good, man. People are sleeping on us. We’ve got players who can play, who have experience, confidence and mental toughness. We know how hard it is to win games, and we know how to play together. We don’t give up. We’re good man."

Toronto has a strong starting five with Lowry, Siakam, VanVleet, Marc Gasol and OG Anunoby, with Ibaka and Powell off the bench. Yes, they lack depth and will have to develop that end of the roster.

But Siakam is a potential All-Star, All-NBA and All-Defensive performer who is not Leonard but still a very talented and unique player the way he operates on both ends of the floor. He’s going to get better, too.

Ibaka’s sentiment is shared throughout Toronto’s locker room.

"I keep saying this, there’s some really special players on this team," Nurse said. "They can do a lot. They like to guard. They know how to guard. They can move the ball. They can shoot the ball. I’m expecting to have a really good team."
